Award.AwardTitle: A New Class of Biomaterials Programmed to Regulate Host Body Responses
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to Vanderbilt University is to design novel biomaterials that regulate angiogenesis through control of the host-foreign body inflammatory response. The researchers plan to design novel biomaterials that will respond to inflammatory cells through regulation of oxidative and matrix metalloproteinase (MMP)-mediated degradation. It is anticipated that elucidation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and MMP-mediated mechanisms whereby host inflammatory responses lead to vascularization of implanted scaffolds will provide a more realistic paradigm to improve functional survival of the scaffold. Development of 'smart' biomaterials that respond to changes in the tissue microenvironment is a promising approach for solving challenging problems in regenerative medicine such as angiogenesis, an essential step in tissue regeneration. A growing body of evidence confirms that the processes of angiogenesis and inflammation are interconnected through various molecular mechanisms. The roles of ROS and MMPs in mediating cross-talk between inflammation and angiogenesis have received much attention, since regulation of these mediators causes substantial changes in important pathophysiological processes (e.g., cancer and atherosclerosis). The research and education activities of this project will be integrated with those of the Vanderbilt School for Science and Math, and the Departments of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering and Biomedical Engineering to train students from High School to Graduate level. In addition, the researchers plan to develop grade-appropriate curriculum components that introduce high school students to tissue engineering and other biomaterial related topics.


The primary goal of the proposed project is to create new therapies for healing tissue defects by developing 'smart' biomaterials that respond to the body's healing process. To accomplish this goal, the researchers will investigate the interactions between inflammation, which leads to rejection of the biomaterial from the body, and angiogenesis that promotes healing. The project will integrate research and education through activities aligned with the goals of the Vanderbilt School for Science and Math (VSSM) and the Vanderbilt School of Engineering. VSSM, a part-time high school located on the Vanderbilt campus and dedicated to public high school students, is a joint venture between Vanderbilt and Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools. In conjunction with core instructors at the VSSM, the PI and co-PI will develop grade-appropriate curriculum components that introduce high school students to tissue engineering. Additionally, through research assistantships, graduate and VSSM high school students will gain experience in the creation of biomaterials that improve tissue healing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Angiogenesis is an essential first step in tissue repair and regeneration. Development of “smart” biomaterials that respond to changes in the tissue microenvironment is a potentially promising approach for solving challenging problems in regenerative medicine, such as angiogenesis. The overall objective of this grant application was to design biomaterials that regulate angiogenesis through control of the host-foreign body inflammatory response.

We found that delivery of both a pro-angiogenic C16 peptide and an anti-inflammatory Ac-SDKP peptide promoted angiogenesis, muscle regeneration, and perfusion recovery while minimizing harmful inflammation. As shown in Figure 1A, the angiogenic peptide enhanced formation of new blood vessels (red) and activity of macrophages (yellow), while the anti-inflammatory peptide reduced these responses. Furthermore, delivery of both peptides at the same time increased blood vessel formation (Figure 1B) and decreased activation of macrophages (Figure 1C) compared to treatment with no peptides. These observations show that dual delivery of a pro-angiogenic and anti-inflammatory peptides is useful for enhancing the regenerative response and minimizing the inflammatory response.

We also designed novel poly(thioketal urethane) (PTKUR) scaffolds that degrade by cell-secreted reactive oxygen species without upregulating the inflammatory response.  PTKUR scaffolds were stable and did not degrade in water, but degraded in the presence of oxidative medium. PTKUR scaffolds were made from two types of intermediates: (1) 1,4-butanedithiol (BDT), which is hydrophobic, and (2) 2-mercaptoethylether (MEE), which is more hydrophilic.  These scaffolds were implanted subcutaneously in rats to evaluate cellular infiltration and scaffold degradation. As shown in Figure 2, PTKUR scaffolds prepared from 100% MEE showed improved cellular infiltration compared to the 0% MEE and poly(ester urethane) (PEUR) control scaffolds. Furthermore, MEE PTKUR scaffolds followed the predicted first-order degradation kinetics in response to reactive oxygen species secreted by infiltrating cells.  In contrast, the PEUR scaffold showed undesirable autocatalytic hydrolytic degradation, as evidenced by the rapid loss in scaffold area at 5 – 7 weeks (Figure 2B). Finally, MEE-PTKUR scaffolds maintained space in the tissue defect more effectively, as evidenced by increased wound thickness compared to the PEUR control (Figure 2C).  We are applying this cell-degradable scaffold technology to design new treatments for healing and restoration of bone and skin defects.

Finally, funding from this award was used to design and develop templated scaffolds using 3D printing techniques.  In this process, 3D templates with tunable pore size were printed by fused deposition modeling and filled with a settable polymer.  The template was then dissolved into an organic solvent.  By varying the composition of the settable polymer, templated scaffolds with tunable rigidity were prepared.  In preliminary studies, we found that the pore size and rigidity controlled angiogenesis in mice.  These 3D templated scaffolds are being used in a number of studies to answer other important questions, such as how the properties of trabecular bone influence the progression of cancer-induced bone disease.


Last Modified: 09/27/2014
Modified by: Scott A Guelcher

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Angiogenesis is an essential first step in tissue repair and regeneration. Development of "smart" biomaterials that respond to changes in the tissue microenvironment is a potentially promising approach for solving challenging problems in regenerative medicine, such as angiogenesis. The overall objective of this grant application was to design biomaterials that regulate angiogenesis through control of the host-foreign body inflammatory response. We found that delivery of both a pro-angiogenic C16 peptide and an anti-inflammatory Ac-SDKP peptide promoted angiogenesis, muscle regeneration, and perfusion recovery while minimizing harmful inflammation. As shown in Figure 1A, the angiogenic peptide enhanced formation of new blood vessels (red) and activity of macrophages (yellow), while the anti-inflammatory peptide reduced these responses. Furthermore, delivery of both peptides at the same time increased blood vessel formation (Figure 1B) and decreased activation of macrophages (Figure 1C) compared to treatment with no peptides. These observations show that dual delivery of a pro-angiogenic and anti-inflammatory peptides is useful for enhancing the regenerative response and minimizing the inflammatory response. We also designed novel poly(thioketal urethane) (PTKUR) scaffolds that degrade by cell-secreted reactive oxygen species without upregulating the inflammatory response. PTKUR scaffolds were stable and did not degrade in water, but degraded in the presence of oxidative medium. PTKUR scaffolds were made from two types of intermediates: (1) 1,4-butanedithiol (BDT), which is hydrophobic, and (2) 2-mercaptoethylether (MEE), which is more hydrophilic. These scaffolds were implanted subcutaneously in rats to evaluate cellular infiltration and scaffold degradation. As shown in Figure 2, PTKUR scaffolds prepared from 100% MEE showed improved cellular infiltration compared to the 0% MEE and poly(ester urethane) (PEUR) control scaffolds. Furthermore, MEE PTKUR scaffolds followed the predicted first-order degradation kinetics in response to reactive oxygen species secreted by infiltrating cells. In contrast, the PEUR scaffold showed undesirable autocatalytic hydrolytic degradation, as evidenced by the rapid loss in scaffold area at 5 – 7 weeks (Figure 2B). Finally, MEE-PTKUR scaffolds maintained space in the tissue defect more effectively, as evidenced by increased wound thickness compared to the PEUR control (Figure 2C). We are applying this cell-degradable scaffold technology to design new treatments for healing and restoration of bone and skin defects. Finally, funding from this award was used to design and develop templated scaffolds using 3D printing techniques. In this process, 3D templates with tunable pore size were printed by fused deposition modeling and filled with a settable polymer. The template was then dissolved into an organic solvent. By varying the composition of the settable polymer, templated scaffolds with tunable rigidity were prepared. In preliminary studies, we found that the pore size and rigidity controlled angiogenesis in mice. These 3D templated scaffolds are being used in a number of studies to answer other important questions, such as how the properties of trabecular bone influence the progression of cancer-induced bone disease.
